abstract: Banks are trying to wow their audiences with better-than-expected numbers, but investors aren’t buying it for a second.
snippet: Banks are trying to wow their audiences with better-than-expected numbers, but investors aren’t buying it for a second.
lead_paragraph: This is starting to feel like amateur hour for aspiring magicians.

headline.main: Bank Profits Appear Out of Thin Air
headline.print_headline: Bank Profits Appear Out Of Thin Air

abstract: Wall Street’s nagging fears about the financial system resurfaced on Monday, pushing stocks sharply lower. Even as the banking giant Bank of America posted big profits, investors fretted about losses and other write-downs that could be lurking, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reported.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s nagging fears about the financial system resurfaced on Monday, pushing stocks sharply lower. Even as the banking giant Bank of America posted big profits, investors fretted about losses and other write-downs that could be lurking, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reported.

headline.main: A New Round of Worries Pushes Shares Lower

abstract: After a strong rally lifted financial stocks 80 percent in just six weeks, Wall Street is once again becoming nervous about the big banks.
lead_paragraph: After a strong rally lifted financial stocks 80 percent in just six weeks, Wall Street is once again becoming nervous about the big banks.

headline.main: Despite Earnings, Questions Dog Bank of America

abstract: Some of the nation’s most influential financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America, cut their political donations, even as Congress began to prepare for increased regulation of the troubled industry, Bloomberg News reported.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s most influential financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America, cut their political donations, even as Congress began to prepare for increased regulation of the troubled industry, Bloomberg News reported.

headline.main: Banks Cut Back on Political Donations, Report Says

abstract: Connecticut’s state treasurer has become the latest disgruntled Bank of America shareholder to slap down the bank’s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut’s state treasurer has become the latest disgruntled Bank of America shareholder to slap down the bank’s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis.

headline.main: Connecticut Treasurer Opposes Lewis at BofA
